description: This course is an introduction to the basic concepts and standards underlying financial accounting systems. Several important concepts will be studied in detail, including: revenue recognition, inventory, long-lived assets, present value, and long term liabilities. The course emphasizes the construction of the basic financial accounting statements - the income statement, balance sheet, and cash flow statement - as well as their interpretation.
name: LECTURE

values.comments:
ACCT101 is an introduction to the basic concepts and standards underlying financial accounting systems. Several important concepts will be studied in detail, including revenue recognition, inventory, long-lived assets, present value, and long term liabilities. The course emphasizes the construction of the basic financial accounting statements - the income statement, balance sheet, and cash flow statement - as well as their interpretation.

Students, for the most part, agreed that the material of this course, though boring, is useful and relevant to the real world. Many students found the class material helpful, especially from a “financial analyst’s perspective.” The course covered a great deal of material, but the required text book is “nothing less than excellent.”

While the students agreed that Professor Gordon was “clearly very knowledgeable about the course material,” they felt that she was \"unable to stimulate student interest.” Students thought that she “did not command enough respect from the class” but agreed that Professor Gordon was very “nice, friendly and helpful.” She prepares slides for the class, although they frequently contain some errors. Students note that Professor Gordon “answers all questions both in class and via email no matter how silly or irrelevant they may seem.” They also felt that Professor Gordon is very enthusiastic and approachable; one stated that “she actually cared about the students understanding the material.” However, some students felt that Professor Gordon went through the concepts too quickly and should slow down.

Some students found the course “challenging” but felt that they “learned a lot” at the same time. They found that they did well as long as they kept up with the material. Some non-Wharton students also opted to “take this class pass/fail because it seems useful.”
